titleStmt.title: Joseph Dalton Hooker an Alexander von Humboldt. Alexandria, 4. Dezember 1847

editionStmt.p: Joseph Dalton Hooker an Alexander von Humboldt. Alexandria, 4. Dezember 1847, hg. v. Sabine Seifert. In: edition humboldt digital, hg. v. Ottmar Ette. Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften, Berlin. Version 9 vom 04.07.2023. URL: https://edition-humboldt.de/v9/

physDesc.p:
Joseph Dalton Hookers Brief endet mit einer Pflanzenliste (Bl. 3v). Im Überlieferungskontext sind, dem Brief beiliegend, weitere Pflanzenlisten erhalten (Bl. 4-9), die hier am Ende des Briefes ediert sind.
Johann Friedrich Klotzsch fertigte eine Abschrift mit Übersetzung der letzten Absätze des Briefes sowie eine Abschrift der Pflanzenliste auf Bl. 3v an. Diese sind mit der Signatur gr. Kasten 12, Nr. 108 überliefert.

div.p:
I very much regretted having to
leave England without answering your long
most excellent & kind letter: full of valuable
information & in every respect of the greatest
service to me. My Father laid it before the
Commissioners of Woods & Forests & the Admiralty,
both of whom attached great importance to it.
At that time I had the offer of going out to
India with Lord Dalhousie the excellent . ,
newly appointed Governor General, & the
time of my departure being thus antici
pated, I was obliged to make my preparations
with great activity: this prevented my
writing to you from England.

My plans have been somewhat altered,
& I would hope for the better, as there is a
p
o ssibility of my visiting Lhassa instead of
N. W. North West
Thibet, whither an Embassy has
already gone 4 months ago & which I could
not have joined before the middle or end
of next year, if then. That Embassy is composed
of 3 persons , .
t T he Naturalist is an intimate friend
& old shoolfellow of my own, Dr Thomson, son
of the Glasgow Professor of Chemistry: he has an
excellent set of instruments & I have forwarded
to him a copy of your instructions,
of which he will fully avail himself.
The i
r object of their mission is, to settle
the boundary line between the territories
of Gholab Sing & Chinese Tartary, & I last
heard from Thomson from the banks of
the Sutledge, on his way to Gartope, where
the party are to meet 3 Chinese Commiss
ioners. This cooperation of the Chinese with
our party, augurs well for the progress of
the expedition. They pass this winter at
Leh & proceed in spring to the N. W. North West , passing
to the Southward of Yarkand & so on to
Kashgar. It is proposed to send another
mission to Lhassa from Calcutta, in the hope
of opening a communication with the Thibet
t
r ibes & should this be carried out I hope
to be allowed to accompany them. Our
route will thus be that followed by
Turner & will I hope throw much light on
the N. North
ch portion of the Himalayah chain.
Should I be disappointed in this my
present intention is to start in March
for Darjeeling, in the Sikkim province, a
little explored country, rich in plants, from
whence I shall if possible push on to
the Snowy range of Bootan, but the Chinese
authorities are so jealous, that my hopes
are not high in that quarter. I shall
however be able to obtain a complete
set of observations at Darjeeling (7.600 ft feet ).
In November I return to Calcutta &
thence go slowly up to the N. W North West provinces
arriving at the End of the cool season at
the mountains, which I shall penetrate
when accessable accessible . Nepaul is I believe
quite closed to Europeans, but from Almorah
I may proceed by the Niti pass to the
lake Masanomawa. Previous to this I
shall have crossed the Vindhya range
on the Nerbudda, so that to vary my
route on returning the 2nd year I may
be induced to take the Malwa provinces
& Mt. Mount Aboe, on the borders of Scinde, & so
down to Bombay.

I need not say that much of the above
is problematical, nor can I fix any-thing
previous to my arrival in Calcutta when
I shall hear about the Lhassa expedition if
it is to be organized.

The Admiralty have further desired my
services in Borneo, to report upon the
vegetable productions of our new settlements
there & I have agreed to proceed thither on
the completion of my Indian journey, I hope
in the year 1849 or 1850. There I shall join Capt. Captain
Keppell’s
Frigate the Meander (44 Guns) & receive every assistance as an officer
in the Navy, with an allowance from the Admiralty for my expenses.
I saw both Capt. Captain
Keppell & Mr Brooke previous to leaving England;
they promise me every assistance, especially towards visiting
Kino Balu, a Mountain estimated 14000 ft. feet at the N.E. North East extreme
of Borneo .
& a highly interesting station for Botany & Meteorological
observations.

The Woods & Forests allow me £400 a year for two years in India,
which will pay a large portion of my expenses. On my proceeding to
Borneo I receive from the Admiralty ,
pay of £230 per annum & an allowance
of £300 a year for my expenses, besides being attached to the Frigates Frigate’s
books for rations on board or ashore.My instruments are all of
the best, chiefly Meterological Meteorological & for objects of Natural History: I
have 3 Barometers: -
1 Siphon (Gay Lussac by Adie of Edinburgh) & 2 of
Newman (cistern) one of 24 in Mts Mountains for great heights. Also a good
boiling water apparatus, Photometer, etc. etc.I shall pay particular
attention to the temperature of Soils & have an instrument for sinking
thermometers. My attention shall of course be chiefly directed to the
effects of climate on vegetation, in all its features . , but I shall avail
myself of every opportunity of investigating Barometric & other pheno
mena of all kinds.

Von hier an bis
Ende u und TabelleDiese Notiz Alexander von Humboldts markiert die Briefstelle, ab der Johann Friedrich Klotzsch eine Abschrift anfertigen sollte. Diese ist mit der Signatur gr. Kasten 12, Nr. 108 überliefert. I did my best before leaving England to prepare a list of all the
Australian plants common to Europe, but could only get through
the Dicotyledones of which I enclose a list. A few others are in Brown’s
AppendixBrown 1814a. Der Text erschien ebenfalls als Einzelpublikation, Brown 1814. to Flinder’s Flinders’s VoyageFlinders 1814., together with the Monocotyledones to
which I had hardly any to add. The preponderance of Cruciferae is
very remarkable, considering how ill-adapted their seeds are for
transport. In the 1st Part of the Flora AntarcticaHooker, J. D. 1844–1860, I. are one or two
additions of Ld Lord Auckland’s group plants found in Europe; and the second
part of the workHooker, J. D. 1844–1860, II. contains all the European species found in Extra
tropical S. South America, some prevailing through intermediate Latitudes,
others as Pisum maritimum & Hippuris vulgaris
s a re sporadic & not
to be met with between the Strait of Magalhanes & the N. Northern temperate
zone. In Ross’ Antarctic VoyageRoss 1847. I have given lists of the Fuegian &
Falkland Land & Ld Lord Auckland & Campbell Island
plants common to those countries & Europe. I endeavored to com
bine all into one list for You before leaving home but was quite
unable to do so, to my very great regret. Coelebogyne still flowers
& ripens its seeds at Kew, as do the plants raised from those seeds
both at Kew & in the Hort. Soc. Horticultural Society Gardens. I have repeatedly examined the
the
stigmata & can find no trace of impregnation, nor of pollen tubes
in the style or mouth of the ovule. In our herbarium we have
native specimens of the male flowers! in small amentaKätzchen: Eine Form des Blütenstands von männlichen und weiblichen Blüten bei Bäumen und Sträuchern..

I have come out so far in HMst V. Her Majesty’s Steam Vessel Sidon, tomorrow we hurry
across to Suez & take the Steamer to Calcutta. The Governor General has
a noble regard for Science & is the youngest man (38.) who has ever been
entrusted with this office: he is every-thing that is good & generous & a man
of first-rate ability.

closer.salute:
Again my dear Baron let me thank You
most warmly. I shall often think of You & all
Your kindness & I hope to send You some results
soon if You will condescend to rec ie ei ve my comm
unications. With feelings of most profound respect
& gratitude Believe me Your affectionate & truly obliged

cell.note: Hooker strich die Angabe unter Punkt 2, korrigierte jedoch nicht die fortlaufende Zählung.

row.cell: Limosella ternifolia a var. variation of L. Limosella aquatica .

div.p:
The above 29 are all Tasmanian & examined
by myself.
Those marked A are also S. South American.
Those marked N. Z. are also New Zealand.

table.head: Plants common to Egypt or Arabia & North West India

Species identical with Americans— or belonging
to genera peculiarly American
—

row.cell:
Oxybaphus himalaicus - valde affinis
O. Odontoglossum Cervantesii

Mirabilis Jalapa - I have found in remote
situations in the Himala most abundantly
so that I cannot but believe it to be
indig enous
.

— Spiræa Lindleyana - v. valde affinis
S. Spiræa sorbifoliæ

div.p:
And were I better acquainted with the Altai
flora, I could doubtless add a considerable
number more —

table.head: European or Levantine Plants, found in Northern India

cell.note: Die Bedeutung der Abkürzungen "a" und "s" ist unsicher. Eventuell markieren sie, dass die genannte Pflanze ebenfalls im Altaigebirge (a) bzw. in Sibirien (s) vorkommt, in Fortführung der Liste auf Bl. 5r.

Hookers fortlaufende Zählung ist hier nicht korrekt. An dieser Stelle handelt es sich um Eintrag Nr. 41. Auch im weiteren Verlauf dieser Liste weicht die Zählung, teils durch spätere Hinzufügungen, an verschiedenen Stellen von der tatsächlichen Anzahl der Einträge ab.

row.cell:
Agrimonia (Nepalensis .
id. idem ac .
A. Agrimonia )hepatoria

not cultivated but truly
wild — Himala

div.p:
The above have been collected by myself —
to these may be added on other authority . :

cell.note: Agrostographia synoptica sive enumeratio graminearum omnium hucusque cognitarum, adjectis characteribus, differentiis et synonymis (Kunth 1833–1850, I/II).

div.p:
Dr Falconer found in Cashmir Pyrola uniflora
& a second species Adoxa — besides other European forms —
